title: Growing Up There Was One Rule. NEVER Open The Door in The Basement.
full_text:
I pulled into the gravel driveway and sat there for a moment, engine ticking as it cooled. Three months. That's how long it had been since we buried Dad, and I still hadn't dealt with any of his stuff. The house looked smaller than I remembered, but maybe that was just perspective. Everything seemed smaller when you were 32 instead of 18. The Victorian's white paint was peeling worse now, and the wraparound porch sagged a little more on the left side. Dad had always been meticulous about maintenance, but the last few years he'd let things slide. I should have noticed that when I visited, should have asked if he needed help. But Dad wasn't the type to ask for help with anything, and I'd been too wrapped up in my own life to push the issue. I grabbed my keys and headed up the front steps, each one groaning under my weight just like they had when I was a kid sneaking in past curfew. The spare key was still under the third flower pot from the left, exactly where it had been for 20 years. Dad never changed his routines. The front door swung open with a familiar squeal, and I stepped into the entryway. The smell hit me immediately, that mixture of old wood, dust, and something else I couldn't quite place, something that had always been part of this house. It wasn't unpleasant, just distinctive. Dad's smell, I guess, though that made it sound worse than it was. Everything looked exactly the same. The narrow hallway stretched ahead of me, dark hardwood floors worn smooth in the center from decades of footsteps. Family photos lined the walls in mismatched frames. Me at various ages, school pictures with awkward smiles and bad haircuts, a few of Mom before she died when I was 12. Dad had never taken those down, never moved on to someone else, just threw himself into work in raising me. I walked into the living room and set my jacket on the back of Dad's recliner. The brown leather was cracked and faded, shaped perfectly to his body after years of use. He'd sit there every evening after dinner, reading or watching the news, always with a cup of black coffee even though it was probably too late in the day for caffeine. I used to sit on the couch and do homework while he read, both of us comfortable in the quiet. The silence felt different now. Before, it had been peaceful, companionable. Now, it pressed against my ears, heavy and expectant, like the house was waiting for something. I needed to start somewhere, so I headed upstairs to Dad's bedroom. Might as well tackle the most personal stuff first, get it over with. The stairs creaked with each step, a symphony of sounds I could probably play from memory. Third step squeaked on the right side. Seventh step groaned in the middle. Tenth step was solid, but the banister wobbled. Dad's room was neat as always, bed made with military corners, dresser top clear except for a small wooden box where he kept his watch and wallet. The closet held rows of identical work shirts and slacks, everything pressed and organized by color. It was going to be heartbreaking to pack all this up, but someone had to do it. I pulled a cardboard box from the stack I'd brought and started with the dresser. Socks, underwear, undershirts, all the mundane stuff that made up a life. It felt invasive going through his things, even though he was gone, like I was violating some unspoken boundary between father and son. The wooden box on top held his watch, a simple silver Timex he'd worn every day for as long as I could remember. I slipped it into my pocket instead of the donation box. Some things were worth keeping. As I worked, my mind kept drifting to all the conversations we'd never had. Dad wasn't much of a talker, especially about personal things. He'd taught me practical stuff, how to change a tire, balance a checkbook, throw a decent punch if I needed to, but we'd never really talked about life, about feelings, or fears, or dreams. I'd always assumed we'd have time for that later when I was older, when he was ready. Now there was no later. I moved to the closet and started pulling shirts off hangers. Most of these could be donated. Dad had been roughly my size, but his style was definitely not mine. Too formal, too buttoned up. I preferred jeans and sweaters, casual clothes that didn't make me feel like I was playing dress up. The afternoon wore on, and I made decent progress. Dresser cleared, closet half empty, nightstand sorted through. I'd found a few things worth keeping, some old photos, a fountain pen that had been his father's, a book of poetry I'd never known he owned. The rest would go to charity or the trash. But as I worked, I kept thinking about the basement. It was stupid, really. I was 32 years old, and I was still thinking about a childhood promise. But Dad had been so intense about it, so serious. I could still see his face that day when I was eight, when I'd been playing hide and seek with the neighbor kids and had almost gone downstairs. He'd grabbed my shoulders, his fingers digging in hard enough to leave bruises. His dark eyes had been wild, desperate in a way that scared me more than any monster under the bed ever could. "Promise me, Evan. Promise me you'll never go down there." I'd promised, of course. What eight-year-old wouldn't promise when their father looked at them like that? And I'd kept that promise through everything, childhood curiosity, teenage rebellion, adult skepticism.Even when I'd started wondering if Dad had some kind of mental health issue, some paranoia or obsession I didn't understand, I'd never broken that promise. The basement door had always been locked anyway, heavy deadbolt that Dad kept the key to, though I'd never seen where he kept it. Sometimes I'd hear him down there moving around, but he never talked about what he was doing. Just house maintenance if I asked, delivered in a tone that made it clear the subject was closed. I finished packing another box and carried it downstairs to the growing pile by the front door. The hallway felt longer than it should have, shadows stretching from the afternoon sun slanting through the windows. And there, at the end of the hall, was the basement door. It looked ordinary enough. White paint, brass knob, same as all the other doors in the house. But it had always felt different to me, even as a kid, like it was holding something back. I walked over and stood in front of it, hand hovering over the doorknob. The deadbolt was still engaged, just like always. But for the first time in 24 years, I had the freedom to find that key if I wanted to. Dad wasn't here to stop me, wasn't here to give me that look that made my stomach twist with guilt and fear. What could be down there that was so important to hide? Old furniture? Christmas decorations? Some embarrassing hobby Dad didn't want me to know about? None of those things seemed worth the level of secrecy he'd maintained. But then I remembered the way he'd looked at me that day, not angry, not frustrated, terrified. Like whatever was down there could hurt me in ways I couldn't understand. Maybe it was structural damage. Maybe the foundation was cracked or the stairs were rotted through, and Dad had been too proud to admit the house was falling apart. That would explain the secrecy, the intensity. He wouldn't want me to know he couldn't afford to fix it. Or maybe it was something else entirely, something I wasn't prepared to deal with. I reached for the doorknob, then stopped. My hand was actually shaking, which was ridiculous. I was a grown man for crying out loud. Whatever was down there, it couldn't be worse than my imagination was making it. But Dad's voice echoed in my memory, urgent and desperate. "Promise me, Evan." I'd made that promise to a father who'd love me, who'd raised me alone after Mom died, who'd worked two jobs to keep us afloat, a father who'd never asked much of me except for this one thing, this one boundary he'd needed me to respect. And what kind of son would I be if I broke that promise now when he wasn't even here to explain why it mattered? I pulled my hand back and stepped away from the door. Whatever was down there could stay down there. Some secrets were meant to be kept, and maybe this was one of them. Dad had carried this burden for his whole life without ever asking me to share it. The least I could do was honor that choice. I turned away from the basement door and headed back upstairs. There was still plenty of work to do, Dad's office, the spare bedroom, the attic. Enough to keep me busy for the rest of the day without worrying about locked doors and childhood promises. But as I climbed the stairs, I couldn't shake the feeling that the house was watching me, waiting to see what I would do. And somewhere in the back of my mind, curiosity stirred like a sleeping animal, patient and persistent. I spent the rest of the afternoon sorting through Dad's office, boxing up files and paperwork, trying to focus on the task at hand. But my thoughts kept drifting back to that door, to the weight of secrets I'd never understand, to the promise that had shaped my entire relationship with this house. I stood at the top of the basement stairs, my hand wrapped around the cool metal of the flashlight I'd found in Dad's kitchen drawer. The deadbolt had turned easier than I'd expected. The key was right there in his desk, tucked behind a stack of old tax returns like he'd wanted me to find it eventually. Maybe he had. The wooden steps creaked under my weight as I made my way down, each footfall echoing in the confined space. I swept the flashlight beam ahead of me, watching dust motes dance in the pale circle of light. The basement smelled musty and forgotten, that particular odor of old cardboard and stagnant air that comes from years of disuse. Nothing sinister about it, just an ordinary basement that had been locked away for too long. My heart had been hammering when I first turned that key, but now, three steps from the bottom, the tension in my shoulders was starting to ease. This wasn't the chamber of horrors my eight-year-old imagination had conjured. Dad's warnings, his iron grip on my shoulders, the absolute terror in his voice when he'd made me promise, it all seemed excessive now, standing in what was clearly just storage space. The flashlight beam revealed exactly what I should've expected, furniture draped in white sheets like ghosts of Christmas past, cardboard boxes stacked along the walls, each one labeled in Dad's careful block letters. Holiday decorations, photo albums, 1985-1990, Evan's school papers. I recognized his handwriting immediately, that precise penmanship he'd maintained even as his hands grew shakier in his final years. I moved deeper into the basement, playing the light across the covered shapes.... a dining room table we'd replaced when I was 12, the old television set from the living room, the one with the wood paneling that had finally given up the ghost sometime in the '90s. Everything ordinary, everything explainable. The relief washing over me felt almost physical, like I'd been holding my breath for 24 years and could finally exhale. All those nights as a kid, lying awake and wondering what horrors dad was keeping locked beneath our feet. All those times I'd pressed my ear to the floor, listening for sounds that never came. The dramatic warnings, the locked door, the weight of secrets that had shaped every interaction I'd had with this house, and for what? Old furniture and Christmas ornaments. I pulled the sheet off what turned out to be my childhood bicycle, a red Schwinn with training wheels still attached. The sight of it hit me harder than I'd expected. I remember dad teaching me to ride it in the driveway, running alongside me with his hand on the seat, promising he wouldn't let go even as he already had. The bike looked smaller than I remembered, the way childhood things always do. Moving to the boxes, I opened one labeled Evan's Toys. Inside, carefully wrapped in tissue paper were action figures I'd forgotten I owned, board games with pieces still in their original plastic bags, a wooden train set dad had built for my sixth birthday. He'd saved everything. Even after locking this place away, making it forbidden territory, he'd preserved every piece of my childhood like a museum curator. The guilt started creeping in then, cold and familiar. Here I was, three months after burying him, finally understanding that his mysterious basement was just a father's way of holding onto memories. Maybe the lock hadn't been about keeping me out. Maybe it had been about keeping the past safe, preserving something precious in a world that moved too fast and threw too much away. I should've asked him about it while I had the chance, should've pushed past his warnings and demanded an explanation. Instead, I'd let childhood fear and respect for his authority keep me ignorant right up until the end. Now, he was gone and I was standing in a room full of carefully preserved love, feeling like an intruder in my own history. The photo albums drew me next. I opened one at random and found myself looking at pictures I'd never seen before. Me as a toddler, covered in finger paint and grinning at the camera. Dad pushing me on a swing set that had been gone by the time I started forming real memories. Mom holding me in the hospital, looking exhausted and radiant in that way new mothers do in movies. I sat down on an overturned crate and flipped through more pages, the flashlight propped against the box to free up both hands. Here was our family before I was old enough to understand what we were losing, before mom got sick, before the long nights at the hospital and the hushed conversations I wasn't supposed to overhear, before dad became the man who locked doors and issued warnings, who carried weight that bent his shoulders and lined his face. The pictures told a different story than the one I remembered. They showed a man who laughed easily, who got down on the floor to play with toy cars, who looked at his wife like she hung the moon. The dad in these photos wasn't the stern guardian of secrets I'd grown up with. He was just a father who loved his family and thought he had all the time in the world to show it. I was so absorbed in the albums that I almost missed it, the door at the far end of the basement, painted the same dull green as the walls, nearly invisible in the shifting shadows cast by my flashlight. If I hadn't stood up to stretch my back, if the beam hadn't swept across that section of wall at just the right angle, I might've spent the whole afternoon down there and never noticed it at all. But I did notice it, and once I had, I couldn't look away. The door was wrong in ways that made my brain struggle to process what I was seeing. No handle. No visible lock. No hinges on the outside, which meant it had to open inward, but that didn't make sense for a basement door. The paint was the exact same shade and finish as the surrounding walls, like someone had worked very hard to make it disappear. I approached it slowly, the way you might approach a sleeping animal you weren't sure was friendly. The closer I got, the more details emerged that shouldn't have been there. The doorframe was seamless, fitted so precisely into the wall that I had to run my fingers along the edges to confirm there was actually an opening there. The paint wasn't just the same color as the walls. It was the same paint applied in the same brush strokes, as if someone had painted the entire wall and then cut a door-shaped hole through it afterward. My hands explored the smooth surface, searching for any kind of mechanism, any way to open it. There had to be something. Doors existed to be opened, but this one defied every expectation I had about how doors should work. It felt solid under my palms, not hollow like an interior door should be. More than solid, it felt heavy, substantial, like it was made of something denser than wood. The logical part of my mind was working overtime trying to make sense of what I was looking at. Maybe it was a sealed entrance to a crawl space. Maybe dad had walled off a section of the basement that had structural problems. Maybe it wasn't actually a door at all, just a weird architectural quirk that looked door shaped in the flashlight beam. But even as I told myself these reasonable explanations, my gut was telling me something different.This door was the real reason for dad's warnings, not the Christmas decorations or the photo albums or the childhood bicycle. This thing, whatever it was, whatever was behind it. I knocked three times before I realized I was going to do it, just a simple rap of my knuckles against the painted surface, the kind of polite knock you'd use at a friend's house. I wasn't expecting anything to happen. I was just testing the solidity of the surface, confirming it was really there and not some trick of shadow and wishful thinking. The voice that answered from the other side nearly stopped my heart. "Hello?" It was young, maybe a child's voice, trembling with what sounded like fear and desperate hope. "Is someone there? Please, I can hear you out there." I jerked my hand back from the door like it had burned me, stumbling backward until my shoulders hit the opposite wall. The flashlight beam wavered wildly as my hands shook, casting crazy shadows that made the basement feel suddenly alive and threatening. "My name is Dale," the voice continued, stronger now, as if my presence had given it courage. "Dale Newman. I've been locked in here for so long. Please, can you help me? I don't know how long it's been, but I've been calling and calling, and no one ever answers." My heart was racing so hard I could feel it in my throat, in my temples, in my fingertips where they gripped the flashlight. Someone was behind that door. Someone was actually trapped back there, and I was the first person to hear them in God knew how long. My back pressed against the concrete wall, flashlight beam dancing across the basement ceiling as my hands shook. Every rational part of my brain was screaming at me to drop the flashlight, run up those stairs, and never come back, lock the basement door, throw away the key, pretend this never happened, but I couldn't move. "Please don't go," the voice said again, and there was something in it that made my chest tighten. Raw desperation, but underneath that, a kind of innocence that reminded me of being nine years old myself, calling for dad when I'd had a nightmare. "I know this must be scary for you. It's scary for me too. I've been alone for so long." I opened my mouth to respond, then closed it. What was I supposed to say? This was impossible. People didn't survive locked in basements for decades. They didn't just appear behind doors that had no handles, no visible way to open them. This had to be some kind of hallucination brought on by stress or grief, or maybe carbon monoxide poisoning from the old furnace. "My name is Dale Newman," the voice continued, and I could hear him moving around in there, footsteps on what sounded like wooden floorboards. "I'm nine years old, or I was nine when my mother brought me here. I don't know how old I am now. Do you know what year it is?" The question hit me like a physical blow. I found myself answering before I could stop myself. "It's 2023." Silence from behind the door, then a sound that might have been crying or laughing or both. "50 years," Dale whispered. "She said she'd come back. She promised she'd come back for me." I closed my eyes, trying to make sense of what I was hearing. The voice sounded like a child, high and clear, but there was something else in it now, a weariness that no nine-year-old should have, like an old man's exhaustion wrapped in a boy's voice. "Who brought you here?" I asked, surprising myself again. I should've been running. I should've been calling the police. Instead, I was having a conversation with someone who claimed to have been trapped in my father's basement since 1973. "My mother, Katherine Newman." The name came out like it still hurt to say it. "She was crying when she brought me down here. She kept saying she was sorry, that she didn't have a choice. She said there were bad people looking for us, and this was the only safe place. She said your father was helping us hide." My father. Dad would've been in his 20s in 1973, just starting out as a carpenter, probably working on houses all over town. But hiding a child in his basement? That didn't sound like the man who'd raised me, who'd taught me to always do the right thing, who'd made me promise to stay out of this basement for my own safety. "She locked the door from the outside," Dale continued, "said she'd be back in a few days with food and clothes and maybe some toys. Said once the bad people stop looking, we could go somewhere far away where we'd be safe, but she never came back." I thought about the door I was leaning against. No handle on this side, no visible lock mechanism. If someone had locked it from the outside 50 years ago, how was Dale still alive? How had he survived without food, without water, without anyone knowing he was there? "How did you eat?" I asked, then immediately felt stupid for encouraging this conversation. But I had to know. Some part of my brain was already trying to solve the puzzle, to find the logical explanation that would make this make sense. "Water drips from the ceiling sometimes," Dale said, "and food appears. Not much, and not often. Crackers, sometimes an apple, a piece of bread. I don't know where it comes from. I used to think my mother was sneaking it in somehow, but I never heard her. I never heard anyone until you."The story was impossible, completely, utterly impossible. But the way he told it with such simple honesty made something twist in my stomach. Either this kid was the best actor in the world, or he genuinely believed what he was saying. And if he believed it, if he'd been alone in there for 50 years thinking his mother was going to come back for him... "I'm sorry," I said, and meant it. "I'm sorry she left you." "It's not your fault." Dale's voice was closer to the door now, like he was sitting right on the other side. "You didn't even know I was here. Your father never told you, did he?" Dad. Had he known? All those years of keeping the basement locked, of making me promise never to come down here, had he been protecting some terrible secret? Had he been the one leaving food for a trapped child, keeping him alive, but never setting him free? "No," I said. "He never told me." "He was kind to me," Dale said quickly, like he was worried I might think badly of Dad. "He brought me books sometimes. Comic books and picture books when I was little, then harder ones as I got older. He'd sit right where you're sitting and read to me. He told me stories about you, about how smart you were, how proud he was of you." My throat felt tight. Dad had sat here in this basement reading to a trapped child. All those evenings when he disappeared for an hour or two claiming he had work to do in the basement, he'd been down here with Dale, and he'd never said a word. "Why didn't he let you out?" I asked. "I don't know." Dale's voice got smaller. "I asked him that a lot when I was younger. He always said it wasn't safe yet, that the people who were looking for me were still out there, that my mother had made him promise to keep me hidden until she came back. He said he couldn't break a promise to someone's mother." That sounded like Dad. He'd been big on promises, on keeping your word no matter what. But keeping a child locked up for 50 years? That went beyond keeping promises into something much darker. "The last time I saw him was maybe three months ago," Dale continued. "He seemed different. Tired, sick maybe. He said he might not be able to visit as much anymore. He said if anything happened to him, eventually someone would come down here and find me. I guess that someone was you." Three months ago, right around the time Dad had gotten his diagnosis, right around the time he'd started getting his affairs in order, making sure everything was ready for when he was gone. Had he been planning for this moment? Had he known that eventually I'd break my promise and come down here? I thought about the key, hidden in his desk drawer, but not that well-hidden, like he'd wanted me to find it eventually, like he'd been counting on my curiosity to override my obedience, the way it always had when I was a kid. "I don't understand any of this," I said. "Neither do I," Dale admitted. "I stopped trying to understand it a long time ago. I just tried to survive, to hope that someday someone would let me out." The hope in his voice broke something inside me. This kid, if he really was a kid, had been holding onto hope for 50 years, waiting for his mother to come back, waiting for Dad to say it was safe, waiting for someone, anyone, to care enough to set him free. "Are you hurt?" I asked. "Are you sick? Do you need medical attention?" "I don't think so. I mean, I'm hungry most of the time and I get cold at night, but I'm not hurt. Just tired. Really, really tired." I could hear that exhaustion in his voice. Not physical tiredness, but the bone-deep weariness of someone who'd been waiting for half a century for their life to begin. "Dale?" I said, testing his name out loud. "I'm Evan. Evan Contreras." "I know," he said, and I could hear the smile in his voice. "Your father talked about you all the time. He said you were going to college to study literature. He said you love books almost as much as I do." Almost as much as I do. Present tense, like Dale was still that nine-year-old boy, still discovering new stories, still finding wonder in words on a page. The thought made my chest ache. "What's your favorite book?" I asked. "The one your father read to me last year." "'To Kill a Mockingbird.' I liked Scout. She reminded me of myself, I think. Curious about things she wasn't supposed to know about." Last year. Dad had been reading Harper Lee to a child in the basement last year while I was living my normal life upstairs, completely oblivious. How had I never heard voices? How had I never suspected? "That's a good book," I said. "Do you have any books with you?" Dale asked, and there was such hope in the question that I felt my heart crack a little more. "Not right now, but I could bring some down tomorrow." The words came out before I could stop them. Tomorrow. I was already planning to come back tomorrow to continue this impossible conversation with this impossible child who might or might not be real. "You'd do that?" Dale's voice was bright with excitement. "You'd really come back?" "Yeah," I said, and realized I meant it. "I'll come back."I couldn't leave him alone again. Real or not, possible or impossible, I couldn't walk away from that voice, from that hope, from that 50-year-old loneliness. Dad had sat in this basement reading to Dale for decades. The least I could do was continue the tradition. "Thank you," Dale whispered. "Thank you so much. I was so scared when your father stopped coming. I thought maybe everyone had forgotten about me." "I won't forget," I promised. And just like that, I was committed. Tomorrow, I'd drive back out to Dad's house, unlock the basement door, and come down here to read to a child who'd been waiting for his mother since the Nixon administration. It made no sense. It defied every law of physics and biology I knew, but I was going to do it anyway, because sometimes the right thing to do isn't the logical thing to do. Sometimes you just have to sit in a basement and read stories to someone who needs to hear them. Three weeks had passed since that first conversation with Dale. Three weeks of daily visits to the basement. Three weeks of carrying books down those creaky wooden stairs. Three weeks of sitting on that overturned crate with my back against the concrete wall, reading aloud to a voice behind a door that shouldn't exist. The routine had become almost normal. I'd wake up, grab coffee, drive out to Dad's house, and spend an hour or two in the basement before heading back to my apartment. We'd worked our way through most of the classics I remembered from college, The Great Gatsby, Of Mice and Men, even some Dickens when Dale asked for something longer. His voice had grown stronger over the weeks, more animated when discussing the stories. He developed opinions about the characters, preferences for certain authors. Sometimes I forgot I was talking to someone I'd never seen. But things had started changing about a week ago. Subtle at first, then more obvious with each visit. "Evan?" Dale's voice came through the door as I finished the last chapter of Lord of the Flies. "Can I ask you something?" I closed the book and shifted on the crate. The concrete wall was cold against my shoulder blades, a familiar sensation by now. "Sure. What's on your mind?" "Do you think..." He paused, and I heard what sounded like movement on the other side of the door. "Do you think you could open the door just for a minute?" My hand tightened on the book's spine. This was new territory. In all our conversations, Dale had never asked about the door itself. We talked about books, about the outside world, about my father's visits over the years, but never about opening the door. "I don't think that's a good idea, Dale." "I know, I know. I'm sorry for asking." His voice carried that apologetic tone I'd grown accustomed to, the sound of someone who'd learned not to expect much. "It's just, I haven't seen sunlight in so long. I keep wondering what it looks like now, if it's the same as I remember." The request sat heavy in the basement air. I understood the appeal. 50 years in a windowless room would drive anyone to desperation. But Dad's warnings echoed in my mind, those bruising grips on my eight-year-old shoulders, the intensity in his voice when he made me promise to stay away from the basement. There had to be a reason for all that secrecy. "Maybe someday," I said, knowing it was a weak response. "Let me think about it." "Really?" The hope in his voice made my chest tighten. "You'd really consider it?" I should've said no outright, should've explained that some promises can't be broken, that Dad must have had good reasons for keeping that door locked. Instead, I mumbled something noncommittal and changed the subject to the book we'd just finished. That was a week ago. Since then, the requests had become more frequent. "Evan, I've been thinking about what you said, about maybe opening the door someday." This was two days later during our reading of To Kill a Mockingbird. "I don't need to come out or anything. I just want to see your face. You're the only person who's talked to me in months, and I don't even know what you look like." "Dale, I know your father used to describe you, said you had his eyes, his stubborn streak." A soft laugh came through the door. "But it's not the same as seeing someone, you know? I've been alone for so long." The loneliness in his voice was real. Whatever else might be going on here, that isolation was genuine. I'd heard it in every conversation, the way he'd latch onto any topic that kept me talking, the reluctance in his voice when our sessions ended. 50 years of solitude would break anyone. "I understand," I said. "But I made a promise to my father." "Your father didn't know I was just a kid. If he'd known how scared I get, how much I miss talking to people..." Dale's voice trailed off. "He was kind to me reading all those books, but he never really knew me, not like you do." That phrase bothered me more than I wanted to admit, "Not like you do." What did I really know about Dale beyond his voice and his story? I'd been taking everything he told me at face value, but the rational part of my mind kept raising questions I didn't want to examine too closely, which was why I'd started researching.The Millbrook Public Library had digitized their local newspaper archives going back to the 1940s. I'd spent hours scrolling through 1973, looking for any mention of a missing child named Dale Newman. Missing person reports, police investigations, even obituaries. Nothing. I'd expanded the search to neighboring towns, then to the entire county. Still nothing. Katherine Newman didn't exist in any public records I could find either. No birth certificates, no death certificates, no property records. It was as if the woman Dale described had never lived at all. I'd tried a different approach, searching for any Newman family in the area during the '70s. Found a few, but none with children matching Dale's description. No unexplained disappearances, no family tragedies that might explain a mother hiding her child in someone else's basement. The lack of evidence should've been reassuring, should've suggested that whatever was behind that door, it wasn't actually a child who'd been trapped for 50 years. But when I'd brought up these concerns during yesterday's visit, Dale had been ready with explanations. "My mother was paranoid about official records," he'd said. "She used different names sometimes, paid for things in cash. She was convinced people were watching us, tracking us somehow. That's why she brought me here in the first place." "But surely someone would've noticed a missing child. Teachers, neighbors, relatives." "We moved around a lot. I was homeschooled and Mom didn't trust neighbors. She said they asked too many questions." Dale's voice had grown quiet, the way it did when he talked about his mother. "She was probably right to be careful. Look what happened to us." The explanations were plausible enough. Plenty of families lived off the grid in the '70s, especially in rural areas. A paranoid mother with a sick child might very well avoid official channels, might seek help from someone like my father without involving authorities. It wasn't impossible, but it also felt too convenient. Every question I raised, Dale had an answer for. Every inconsistency in his story came with a reasonable explanation. It was almost as if he'd been preparing for these conversations for years. "Evan?" Dale's voice pulled me back to the present. I'd been sitting in the basement for 10 minutes, lost in thought, the copy of Jane Eyre unopened in my lap. "Sorry, just thinking." "About the door?" The hope in his voice was unmistakable. Over the past week, that hope had grown stronger with each visit. What had started as tentative requests had become the central focus of our conversations. Dale would listen politely while I read, participate in discussions about the books, but eventually every session would circle back to the same plea. "Dale, I need you to understand something.
